titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records
Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff and Alison Clemens

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:05
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

did.unittitle: Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records contains administrative records from the town of Músquiz, Coahuila, Mexico. The records were collected by Luis Alberto Guajardo, a general in the Mexican Army. Guajardo's military travels allowed him to visit local record offices in Coahuila and research the history of the region. This research led to the formulation of Guajardo's Apuntes Datos y Noticias Para la Historia de Coahuila, a history of the Coahuila region. The Records are arranged in five overlapping chronologies. This order has been maintained from an earlier, unknown processor, perhaps Guajardo himself. The chronologies include circulars issued by the Coahuila government; religious, legal, military, land, water, and mining records pertaining to Musquiz and the Coahuila region; census records, including the documentation of Indians, widows, slaves, and vassals; legal records, including records administering issues of violence against women; documents pertaining to the administration of Indian affairs, particularly those of the Seminole and Apache tribes; and indices of correspondence and decrees in Coahuila, wills, and court proceedings. Also included is material on the founding and history of the Texas region, as well as English language manuscript land petitions, citizenship records, and legal proceedings of Thomas Jefferson Chambers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Charles and Lindley Eberstadt, 1961.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing in 2014, including rehousing and minimal organization. Prior processing in the summer of 1993 found that the papers had been arranged in five chronological series. Many documents were dated in pencil by an earlier unknown processor. Without disturbing these series, the chronological order within each series was improved, and the material was placed in archival folders and boxes. No bound documents were disbound.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated material: Luis Alberto Guajardo Papers on the History of Coahuila (WA MSS S-668). Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Luis Alberto Guajardo Collection of Músquiz, Mexico Records contains administrative records from the town of Músquiz, Coahuila, Mexico. The records were collected by Luis Alberto Guajardo, a general in the Mexican Army. Guajardo's military travels allowed him to visit local record offices in Coahuila to research the history of the region, collect documents, and make copies of original documents. This research led to the formulation of Guajardo's Apuntes Datos y Noticias Para la Historia de Coahuila, a history of the Coahuila region. Much of the material contained in this collection appears to have been used in the creation of the Apuntes Datos y Noticias.

The collection is arranged in five overlapping chronologies, apparently created by Guajardo. In some areas of this collection, his manuscript notes are present and indicate how he has grouped material.
The First Chronology is the largest and includes administrative records, particularly census records, land records, legal records, and records pertaining to the administration of Indian affairs.
The Second Chronology is very similar to the First Chronology and includes administrative records and circulars issued by the Coahuila government.
The Third Chronology includes religious, census, property, and legal records pertaining to Músquiz and the Coahuila region.

The Fourth Chronology contains administrative records for the Coahuila region, including census, land, and water records; census rolls, including rolls of Indian (particularly Seminole and Apache) residents; records pertaining to mining in the Santa Rosa region; an account of the founding of Piedras Negras; and records pertaining to the military budget.

The Fifth Chronology includes indices of correspondence and decrees in Coahuila, wills, and court proceedings. The land petitions, citizenship, and legal proceedings of Thomas Jefferson Chambers are especially well documented and include manuscripts in English. This chronology also includes material on the founding and history of the Texas region.

Luis Alberto Guajardo's Folders (now empty) consists of folders Guajardo used. When the collection was processed in 1993 these folders were empty, but the folders have been kept with the collection because they include Guajardo's notes and may provide information regarding how he organized the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Luis Alberto Guajardo (1872-1925) was a general in the Mexican Army. He was born in Músquiz, Coahuila and participated in the Mexican Revolution. His military travels allowed him to visit local record offices in Coahuila and research the history of the region, as well as make copies of original documents. This research led to the formulation of Apuntes Datos y Noticias Para la Historia de Coahuila, a history of the Coahuila region.

did.unittitle: First Chronology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material contained in this chronology primarily consists of administrative records, particularly census records and land records. Some of the documents are bound together and others show signs of having once been bound.

Material contained within the First Chronology includes land grant petitions, particularly in the Santa Rosa Maria del Sacramento region; census records indicating widows, slaves, and vassals; records documenting the administration of legal matters pertaining to violence against women; records describing efforts to manage public health issues, particularly cholera and syphilis; and records pertaining to government management of Indian groups in the 18th and 19th centuries, particularly Apache groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes land grant petitions and administrative records issued by Pablo Mauricio de la Garza Falcon and Miguel de la Garza Falcon.

did.unittitle: Will of José Gregorio Sanchez (probably labeled by Guajardo)

scopecontent.p: Includes census records and records of widows, slaves, and vassals.

Part II of 1824 (probably labeled by Guajardo)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes descriptions of plans to prevent the spread of cholera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes descriptions of abuse against women, including domestic violence and keeping a concubine, and the associated fines levied by municipal authorities against perpetrators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes testimonies of domestic violence and sexual assault.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes descriptions of efforts to remove a servant and a syphilitic American due to their infection with the disease and rumors of filibusterers gathering on the Rio Grande.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a description of a dispute over a doctor failing to report a contagious disease in Músquiz.

did.unittitle: Second Chronology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Second Chronology is very similar to the first and includes administrative records and circulars issued by the Coahuila government. Many of the documents in this chronology pertain to municipal budgetary matters; the budget of the city of Músquiz; municipal government sessions; the Mexican army, particularly the Ejercito del Norte; and the enforcement of the Catholic faith in the country. Some documents have been numbered, some are bound, and many show signs of having once been sewn together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes circulars pertaining to the government budget of Músquiz

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes records of governmental sessions

did.unittitle: Part I of 1860
Part II of 1860
Third Chronology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Third Chronology includes religious, census, property, and legal records pertaining to Músquiz and the Coahuila region. Local registers of citizens, including Indians, are included in this chronology, as are legal hereditary records, commerce records for the region, government correspondence records, and records about mining in the Santa Rosa region. The chronology consists primarily of bound manuscripts; many of these items are accompanied by notes in Guajardo's hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes church, census, and property records

did.unittitle: Fourth Chronology

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order by units of documents grouped by Luis Alberto Guajardo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fourth Chronology contains administrative records for the Coahuila region, including census, land, and water records; census rolls, including registers of Indian residents; records pertaining to mining in the Santa Rosa region; an account of the founding of Piedras Negras; and records pertaining to the military budget. Throughout this chronology there are autograph notes in the hand of Luis Alberto Guajardo that indicate that these records were being used in the formation of Apuntes Datos y Noticias Para la Historia de Coahuila.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes land and census records

scopecontent.p: Includes census rolls and records pertaining to Indians in the region

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Fifth Chronology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fifth chronology includes indices of correspondence and decrees in Coahuila, wills, and court proceedings. The land petitions, citizenship, and legal proceedings of Thomas Jefferson Chambers are especially well documented and include manuscripts in English. This chronology also includes material on the founding and history of the Texas region.

Throughout this section there are autograph notes in the hand of Luis A. Guajardo suggesting an an order he imposed while creating Apuntes Datos y Noticias Para la Historia de Coahuila. Some of the folders were labeled by an unknown earlier processor and those titles have been maintained. Titles in brackets were provided in the summer of 1993.

Luis Alberto Guajardo's Folders (now empty)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are folders used by Guajardo to house the material in the collection. Many of these folders include his manuscript notes. The folders were emptied by an unknown, earlier processor but have been kept with the collection in order to preserve his notes.
